content:
For validator 4

103121112108

How do you choose between different possible outputs?

103.12.111.2.108 -> g12o2l
103.121.1.121.08 -> gy1y08
103.121.112.108 -> gypl

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is good and fun! Definitely deserve to be approved.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Seems like a fun challenge for clash! Good idea!
This is good!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I relished the delightful challenge of this exceptional puzzle, reveling in its ingenuity and creative brilliance. It was an absolute joy to solve.
Alright, the clash has been modified back to normal! You can give your suggestions or approve/reject the clash now.
I find great pleasure in the concept of this puzzle, yet I kindly request alterations to its solution and test cases. Once these adjustments are made, I shall gladly give my approval :)
If there's any significant errors you notice, please wait for some time, someone has absolutely demolished this contribution and even the answer is changed; it would take some time to fix it.
remove the excess highlighting in the story

Goal
* Please explain the compression method before you provide the example. Examples should not be treated as a substitute for explanations.

Output
* Please change "Line 2" to "Line 1".

Thanks.

STORY:
* Second Sentence: "Your boss has been talking about how the company spends a lot of money buying servers to handle the numbers."

CONSTRAINTS:
* Rewrite your 1st constraint as "0 <= length of [[number]] <= 15", or "0 < [[number]] < 100,000,000,000,000".

MODES:
* Please remove REVERSE mode. In REVERSE mode there is no description, input or output, which would make it very hard for the coder to understand what to do.

Apart from that, a good clash.

Thanks,

1) Second sentence seems fine to me, expends is a synonym for spends.
2) The limit has already been specified in terms of characters (3 to 15, both inclusive.)
3) I mean, even if the first test cases didn't make the solution obvious in reverse mode, you can pretty much see it clearly in test cases 2, where the input and output have 03011 in common, and other than that, 102 is replaced with f, from which it's pretty easy to figure out that 102 is the ASCII number for f.
You can suggest any other mistakes if you see them.
Thank you.
OK, will change. It was Line 1, no idea, how it changed to Line 2. My contributions have been changing a lot now that I see them once again.

Oh, I didn't make that much of a mess.
Someone's been messing with my code lately, need to figure out who it is.
Thanks for pointing it out.
Really? If necessary, please report to CG staff for their investigation.

I am writing this comment to express my sincere gratitude in response to your eccentric but profound and elaborate review of my contribution; it gives me such depths of happiness and elation that my creation has been cherished by a well-experienced user.

Oh, I really didn't think that would be an ambiguous case; in my opinion, I think the given problem statement explains it as needed.

"The basic idea behind the compression is to scan, from left to right, the substrings in the given number, and *whenever* a substring is found to be the ASCII number of an English letter, replace the substring with the letter."

The reason your code isn't working might be because of trying a method which does not necessarily scan the string from left to right.

Anyways, I will try to clarify it further by elaborating on the example.

Yes, but it works on all Tests, it only fails on a Validator. For Shortest mode I always try a few different approaches, and keep the shortest one if it passes all Tests.

In this case, the .replace approach results in much, much shorter code than the left-to-right approach, and it passes all Tests. It's a bit unfair to have all Tests don't care about the order, but then spring a surprise Validator which does care.

It's unfair too for Reverse mode, which doesn't have the left-to-right explanation at all, so it's an even bigger surprise.

So I really think that you should add a Test for which the order matters!
OK, so that is the issue; modified test 4.
Oh never mind. I saw you do so already.

That looks better. Suggest to rewrite the compression method as follows:

The basic idea behind the compression is to scan, from left to right, the substrings in the given number, and whenever a substring is found to be the ASCII number of an English letter, replace the substring with the letter. Other digits are kept unchanged.

Notes:
(1) There is a distinction between "alphabet" and "letter": the English alphabet consists of 26 letters.

(2) It's necessary to mention the scan is from left to right, so replacements should not be made in any other manner.

(3) It's necessary to mention the treatment ("kept unchanged") of the digits which do not form part of any ASCII number of a letter.

Thanks.

Yeah, my bad. Thanks.
I didn't mention the third part since only the letters are "replaced", implying that nothing happens to the numbers, but I guess I needed to mention that to clear any ambiguity.

Thanks for replying.

1) I didn't know about "expends" as a synonym for "spends"... cool.
2) Very good.
3) I understand now.

Never-mind my corrections... your clash seems good to go.

Thanks,
Code-Parser

2) It's weird to state on one hand that the input is a number, and on the other hand its constraint in terms of length (as a string). It's better to describe the input as a string of digits instead of a number (the player won't treat the whole string as a number anyway, at most just part of it).

3) Let's see what other players think. I guess only more experienced players are able to make the connection.

Thanks.

Yeah, I was thinking on what to do for the second part. The input consists of a number, but it's easier to handle it as a string and it's awkward to just convert a number back to a string when you already can directly take it as one.
I guess I'll just replace number with "a string of digits"
And yeah, now that I think of it, I can't be very sure if others find it easy on reverse mode. We'll wait for others to validate, I guess.
Thank you.
